fields.description:
Fast Charge Current Regulation Limit with 5mΩ RBAT_SNS:
Actual charge current is the lower of ICHG_REG and
ICHG pin
POR: 20000mA (190h)
Range: 400mA-20000mA (8h-190h)
Bit Step: 50mA
fields.name: ICHG_REG

fields.description:
Input Current DPM Regulation Limit with 5mΩ RAC_SNS:
Actual input current limit is the lower of IAC_DPM and
ILIM_HIZ pin
POR: 20000mA (190h)
Range: 400mA-20000mA (8h-190h)
Bit Step: 50mA
fields.name: IAC_DPM

fields.description:
Input Voltage Regulation Limit:
Note if EN_MPPT = 1, the Full Sweep method will use
this limit as the lower search window for Full Panel
Sweep
POR: 4200mV (D2h)
Range: 4200mV-65000mV (D2h-CB2h)
Bit Step: 20mV
fields.name: VAC_DPM

fields.description:
Input Current Regulation in Reverse Mode with 5mΩ
RAC_SNS:
POR: 20000mA (190h)
Range: 400mA-20000mA (8h-190h)
Bit Step: 50mA
fields.name: IAC_REV

fields.description:
VAC Voltage Regulation in Reverse Mode:
POR: 5000mV (FAh)
Range: 3300mV-65000mV (A5h-CB2h)
Bit Step: 20mV
fields.name: VAC_REV

fields.description:
Pre-charge current regulation limit with 5mΩ
RBAT_SNS:
Actual pre-charge current
is the lower of IPRECHG
and ICHG pin
POR: 4000mA (50h)
Range: 250mA-10000mA (5h-C8h)
Bit Step: 50mA
fields.name: IPRECHG

fields.description:
Termination Current Threshold with 5mΩ RBAT_SNS:
Actual termination current
is the lower of ITERM and
ICHG pin if both functions
enabled
POR: 2000mA (28h)
Range: 250mA-10000mA (5h-C8h)
Bit Step: 50mA
fields.name: ITERM

pulse

FSW_SYNC status change does not produce INT
pulse

pulse

digital_physical_map.1:
Input under-voltage event does not produce INT
pulse

digital_physical_map.1:
Input over-voltage event does not produce INT
pulse

digital_physical_map.1: Start average using new ADC conversion

fields.description:
IAC ADC reading with 5mΩ RAC_SNS:
Reported as 2s complement
POR: 0mA(0h)
Format: 2s Complement
Range: -20000mA - 20000mA (9E58h-61A8h)
Bit Step: 0.8mA
fields.name: IAC_ADC

fields.description:
IBAT ADC reading with 5mΩ RBAT_SNS:
Reported as 2s complement
POR: 0mA (0h)
Format: 2s Complement
Range: -20000mA-20000mA (D8F0h-2710h)
Bit Step: 2mA
fields.name: IBAT_ADC

fields.description:
VAC ADC reading:
Reported as unsigned integer
POR: 0mV (0h)
Format: 2s Complement
Range: 0mV-65534mV (0h-7FFFh)
Bit Step: 2mV
fields.name: VAC_ADC

fields.description:
VBAT ADC reading:
Reported as unsigned integer
POR: 0mV (0h)
Format: 2s Complement
Range: 0mV-65534mV (0h-7FFFh)
Bit Step: 2mV
fields.name: VBAT_ADC

TS ADC reading as percentage of REGN:
Reported as unsigned integer
POR: 0%(0h)
Range: 0% - 99.90234375% (0h-3FFh)
Bit Step: 0.09765625%
fields.name: TS_ADC

fields.description:
VFB ADC reading:
POR: 0mV (0h)
Range: 0mV-2047mV (0h-7FFh)
Bit Step: 1mV
fields.name: VFB_ADC

ACN.description: Adapter Current-Sense Resistor, Negative Input – A 0.47-μF ceramic capacitor is placed from ACN to ACP to provide differential-mode filtering. An optional 0.1-μF ceramic capacitor is placed from the ACN pin to PGND for common-mode filtering.

connected_components.description: This resistor is placed in series with the adapter input to measure the current. ACN connects to the negative terminal of this resistor.
Connects between ACN and ACP for differential-mode filtering.
Connects between ACN and PGND for common-mode filtering.

implementation.connectivity: Connect to the negative terminal of the input current sense resistor. A 0.47-µF ceramic capacitor should be connected between ACN and ACP for differential-mode filtering. An optional 0.1-µF ceramic capacitor can be connected from ACN to PGND for common-mode filtering.
implementation.detailed_description: Adapter Current-Sense Resistor, Negative Input – A 0.47-µF ceramic capacitor is placed from ACN to ACP to provide differential-mode filtering. An optional 0.1-µF ceramic capacitor is placed from the ACN pin to PGND for common-mode filtering.
implementation.functionality: The ACN pin is part of the differential current sensing pair for the adapter input. It works in conjunction with the ACP pin to measure the input current.
implementation.precautions: Ensure proper filtering is applied to the ACN and ACP pins to prevent noise from affecting current measurements. The location of bypass capacitors should be as close as possible to the IC pins.

ACN.name: ACN

ACOV.description: AC Overvoltage Comparator Input – Connect a resistor divider from VAC to PGND to program the overvoltage protection. When this pin rises above VREF_ACOV, the device stops charging. If ACOV programming is not used, pull this pin to PGND, do not leave floating.

connected_components.description: A resistor divider network is connected between VAC and PGND. The ACOV pin is connected to the junction of these resistors. This network sets the overvoltage protection threshold. The values of the resistors (RAC1, RAC2, RAC3) determine the target overvoltage level according to the formula V ACOV_TARGET = V REF_ACOV × (RAC1 + RAC2 + RAC3) / RAC3.
The lower end of the resistor divider is connected to Power Ground (PGND).
The upper end of the resistor divider is connected to the input voltage source (VAC).

implementation.connectivity: ACOV should be connected to a resistor divider network from the VAC pin to PGND to set the desired overvoltage protection threshold (V_ACOV_TARGET). Alternatively, if the internal overvoltage protection is desired, ACOV should be tied to PGND.
implementation.detailed_description: ACOV is the AC Overvoltage Comparator Input pin. It is used to program the overvoltage protection for the input voltage. When this pin rises above its reference voltage (VREF_ACOV), the device stops charging and pulls the PG pin high. It is also used to set the input operating window along with the ACUV pin.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of ACOV is to act as an input for the overvoltage protection comparator. It is connected to a resistor divider from the VAC pin to PGND to set the overvoltage threshold. If the input voltage rises above this programmed threshold, the device will cease charging. If programming is not used, it should be pulled to PGND to enable the internal overvoltage protection.
implementation.precautions: If the ACOV pin is not used for programming the overvoltage protection, it must be tied to PGND to enable the internal overvoltage protection threshold. Failure to do so may result in unpredictable behavior.

ACOV.name: ACOV

ACP.description: Adapter Current-Sense Resistor, Positive Input – A 0.47-μF ceramic capacitor is placed from ACN to ACP to provide differential-mode filtering. A 0.1-μF ceramic capacitor is placed from the ACP pin to PGND for common-mode filtering.

connected_components.description: Adapter Current-Sense Resistor. Typically 2 mΩ or 5 mΩ, placed in series with the adapter input current path.
Optional common-mode filter capacitor (0.1 µF ceramic) connected from ACN to PGND.
Differential-mode filter capacitor (0.47 µF ceramic) connected between ACN and ACP.

implementation.connectivity: Connect in series with the adapter's positive current path, with the negative side of the sense resistor connected to ACN.
implementation.detailed_description: Adapter Current-Sense Resistor, Positive Input. This pin is part of the differential pair used for sensing the input current from the adapter. It is connected in series with the adapter input current path.
implementation.functionality: Primary function is to serve as the positive input for the current sense resistor (R_AC_SNS) to measure the adapter current. It is used in conjunction with the ACN pin for input current regulation and monitoring. It can also be used for common-mode filtering by connecting a capacitor to PGND.
implementation.precautions: Ensure the sense resistor (R_AC_SNS) is properly placed to sense the total input current. The trace routing for ACP and ACN should be a differential pair to minimize noise pickup. A filter capacitor (C_ACN_ACP) between ACP and ACN is recommended for differential-mode filtering. An optional common-mode filter capacitor (C_ACN_PGND) to PGND can also be used. The value of R_AC_SNS affects the input current limit range and accuracy; select it carefully based on application requirements.

ACP.name: ACP

ACUV.description: AC Undervoltage Comparator Input – Connect a resistor divider from VAC to PGND to program the undervoltage protection. When this pin falls below VREF_ACUV, the device stops charging. The hardware limit for input voltage regulation reference is VACUV_DPM. The actual input voltage regulation is the higher of the pin-programmed value and the VAC_DPM register value. If ACUV programming is not used, pull this pin to VAC, do not leave floating.

connected_components.description: A resistor divider is connected between the VAC pin and PGND, with the junction connected to the ACUV pin. The values of these resistors determine the undervoltage protection threshold.

implementation.connectivity: Connect a resistor divider from the VAC pin to PGND to this pin to program the undervoltage protection. If ACUV programming is not used, this pin should be connected to VAC, and not left floating.
implementation.detailed_description: The ACUV pin is the AC Undervoltage Comparator Input. It is used in conjunction with a resistor divider from the VAC pin to PGND to program the undervoltage protection for the input voltage. When the voltage at this pin falls below the internal reference (VREF_ACUV), the device stops charging. The hardware limit for input voltage regulation reference is VACUV_DPM. The actual input voltage regulation is determined by the higher of the value programmed by the ACUV pin and the VAC_DPM register value.
implementation.functionality: The ACUV pin's primary function is to set the undervoltage protection threshold. If this pin's voltage falls below VREF_ACUV, charging is halted.  In conjunction with the VAC_DPM register, it defines the input voltage regulation limit.
implementation.precautions: If ACUV programming is not used, ensure the pin is tied to VAC and not left floating. The voltage on this pin dictates the lower limit of the input voltage operating window, and misconfiguration can lead to unexpected charging behavior or shutdown.

ACUV.name: ACUV

BTST1.description: Buck Side High-Side Power MOSFET Gate Driver Power Supply – Connect a capacitor between BTST1 and SW1 to provide bias to the high-side MOSFET gate driver.

connected_components.description: A bootstrap capacitor is required to be connected between the BTST1 pin and the SW1 pin. A typical value for this capacitor is 0.1 uF. This capacitor is used to store the charge that powers the high-side gate driver.

implementation.connectivity: Connect a capacitor between BTST1 and SW1.
implementation.detailed_description: The BTST1 pin is the power supply for the high-side gate driver for the buck side. It works in conjunction with the SW1 pin to provide the necessary voltage to drive the high-side N-channel MOSFET gate.
implementation.functionality: BTST1 is used as a bootstrap power supply for the high-side gate driver. A capacitor connected between BTST1 and SW1 allows the high-side driver to charge up when the low-side FET is on. When the low-side FET turns off and the high-side FET turns on, the voltage on SW1 rises, and the capacitor connected between BTST1 and SW1 provides the boosted voltage to drive the high-side FET gate. The voltage on BTST1 is therefore approximately VGS + VSW1, where VSW1 is the voltage on the SW1 pin.
precautions: Ensure the bootstrap capacitor is connected between BTST1 and SW1.
Do not leave the BTST1 pin floating.
The voltage on BTST1 relative to SW1 should not exceed the absolute maximum rating of 14V.
The voltage on BTST1 relative to PGND should not exceed the absolute maximum rating of 6V.

BTST1.name: BTST1

BTST2.description: Boost Side High-Side Power MOSFET Gate Driver Power Supply – Connect a capacitor between BTST2 and SW2 to provide bias to the high-side MOSFET gate driver.

connected_components.details: A ceramic capacitor is used as a bootstrap capacitor. The typical value recommended in the datasheet is not explicitly stated for BTST2, but for BTST1 it is 0.47-μF. It's generally a good practice to use a ceramic capacitor with a voltage rating higher than the maximum expected voltage difference between BTST2 and SW2.

implementation.connectivity: Connect a capacitor between the BTST2 pin and the SW2 pin.
implementation.detailed_description: BTST2 is the bootstrap power supply for the high-side gate driver of the boost side. It is used in conjunction with an external capacitor to provide the necessary bias voltage for the high-side MOSFET gate driver.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of BTST2 is to provide a floating power supply to the high-side gate driver. This is achieved by using an external bootstrap capacitor connected between BTST2 and SW2. During the low-side FET's ON time, the bootstrap capacitor is charged. When the high-side FET needs to be turned on, the voltage at BTST2 is raised above SW2 by the voltage stored in the bootstrap capacitor, enabling the gate driver.
precautions: The BTST2 pin is a power supply for the high-side gate driver and should not be left floating.
Ensure the bootstrap capacitor is placed as close as possible to the IC pins (BTST2 and SW2) to minimize parasitic inductance.
The voltage rating of the bootstrap capacitor should be sufficient to handle the voltage difference between BTST2 and SW2 during operation.

BTST2.name: BTST2

CE.description: Active Low Charge Enable Pin – Battery charging is enabled when EN_CHG bit is 1 and CE pin is LOW. CE pin must be pulled HIGH or LOW, do not leave floating. The CE pin function can be disabled when DIS_CE_PIN bit is set to 1. When disabled, this pin can be used as a general purpose indicator via the FORCE_STAT4_ON bit.

connected_components.details: A digital output pin from a microcontroller can be used to control the charging state by driving the CE pin HIGH (disable charging) or LOW (enable charging).
A pull-up resistor (typically 10 kΩ) to the logic rail can be used to ensure the CE pin is HIGH by default, disabling charging until explicitly enabled by a microcontroller or other logic.

implementation.connectivity: The CE pin must be actively driven HIGH or LOW; it should not be left floating. It can be connected to a logic-level output from a microcontroller or to a pull-up resistor to the logic rail if autonomous operation is desired.
implementation.detailed_description: The CE (Charge Enable) pin is an active low pin that controls the battery charging function. When the EN_CHG bit in the Charger Control register is set to 1 and the CE pin is LOW, battery charging is enabled. If this pin is left floating, it must be pulled HIGH or LOW.
implementation.functionality: The CE pin's primary function is to enable or disable battery charging. Its functionality can also be disabled via the DIS_CE_PIN bit in the Pin Control register. When disabled, this pin can be repurposed as a general-purpose indicator via the FORCE_STAT4_ON bit, which allows it to be controlled as a status output.
implementation.precautions: The CE pin must not be left floating; it must be tied either HIGH or LOW. If the pin function is disabled via the DIS_CE_PIN register bit, it can be repurposed as a general-purpose indicator, but care must be taken not to interfere with its primary charging control function when enabled.

CE.name: CE

DRV_SUP.description: Charger Gate Drive Supply Input – Voltage on this pin is used to drive the gates of buck-boost converter switching FET. Connect a 4.7-μF ceramic capacitor from DRV_SUP to power ground. REGN LDO voltage can be used as the gate driver supply for all switching FETs by connecting REGN to DRV_SUP pin. In high-voltage applications, it is possible to directly provide the DRV_SUP voltage with an external supply up to 12 V to achieve higher switching efficiency. See Section 8.3.3.2 for more details.

connected_components.details: A voltage source between 4.5V and 12V, capable of supplying sufficient current to drive the switching FET gates.
Connect to the REGN pin to utilize the internal linear regulator as the gate drive supply.
A 4.7-µF ceramic capacitor connected from DRV_SUP to PGND.

implementation.connectivity: Connect to an external gate drive supply (4.5V to 12V) for high-voltage applications or connect to the REGN pin to use the internal regulator. A 4.7-µF ceramic capacitor should be connected from DRV_SUP to power ground (PGND).
implementation.detailed_description: The DRV_SUP pin serves as the voltage supply input for the charger's gate drive circuitry, which is responsible for driving the gates of the buck-boost converter's switching FETs. This allows for an external supply to provide bias to the gate drivers. The REGN LDO voltage can also be used as the gate driver supply by connecting the REGN pin to the DRV_SUP pin.
implementation.functionality: The DRV_SUP pin's primary function is to supply power to the gate drivers for the switching FETs. In high-voltage applications, it can accept an external supply up to 12V for optimized efficiency. Alternatively, it can be connected to the internal REGN LDO output to utilize the IC's internal regulator for gate drive supply.
implementation.precautions: In high-voltage applications, directly driving the DRV_SUP pin with an external supply up to 12V can improve switching efficiency compared to using the REGN LDO. Ensure the external supply can provide adequate current for the gate drivers. When using the REGN LDO, consider the power dissipation from gate driving via REGN, as it can be excessive in high-voltage applications or with large gate drive requirements. The power dissipation is calculated as P_REGN = (VAC - V_REGN) * Q_G(TOT) * f_SW.

DRV_SUP.name: DRV_SUP

FB.description: Charge Voltage Analog Feedback Adjustment – Connect the output of a resistive voltage divider from the battery terminals to this node to adjust the output battery regulation voltage.

connected_components.description: A voltage divider composed of resistors is used to scale the battery voltage to a level that can be safely read by the FB pin. The values of these resistors determine the charge voltage regulation target. The top resistor connects to the battery positive terminal, and the bottom resistor connects to the FBG pin. The specific resistor values will depend on the desired charge voltage and the internal feedback voltage reference of the BQ25756.

The FBG pin is the return for the voltage feedback divider. When charging, this pin is internally driven to PGND. When the input voltage is outside the ACUV/ACOV operating window, this pin becomes high-impedance to minimize battery leakage current.

implementation.connectivity: The FB pin should be connected to the output of a resistive voltage divider. This voltage divider typically has its top connected to the battery positive terminal and its bottom connected to the FBG pin (or PGND if FBG is not used).
implementation.detailed_description: The FB pin is used for analog feedback adjustment of the charge voltage. It connects to the output of a resistive voltage divider that is connected from the battery terminals.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of the FB pin is to provide feedback for the charge voltage regulation loop. It allows the device to monitor the battery voltage and adjust the charging process accordingly to maintain the desired charge voltage.
implementation.precautions: Ensure the voltage divider ratio is correctly calculated to avoid overcharging or undercharging the battery. The voltage at the FB pin should not exceed the device's absolute maximum ratings. Use resistors with appropriate tolerance (e.g., 0.1%) for accurate voltage regulation.

FB.name: FB

FBG.description: Voltage Feedback Divider Return – Connect to the bottom of battery feedback resistor. When charging, this pin is driven to PGND internally. When input voltage is outside of the ACUV / ACOV operating window, this pin is high-impedance, minimizing battery leakage current.

connected_components.details: A resistor divider network is connected from the battery terminals to the FB pin (for voltage feedback) and the FBG pin. The FBG pin serves as the return for this divider.

implementation.connectivity: Connect this pin to the bottom of the battery voltage feedback resistor divider network.
implementation.detailed_description: The FBG pin is the return path for the voltage feedback divider. When the device is charging, this pin is internally driven to PGND. When the input voltage is outside the ACUV/ACOV operating window, this pin goes to a high-impedance state, which helps to minimize battery leakage current.
implementation.functionality: The primary function is to serve as the return path for the battery voltage feedback divider. In charging mode, it's internally connected to PGND. When the input voltage is out of the operating window, it becomes high-impedance to reduce battery leakage.
precautions: Ensure proper connection to the bottom of the feedback resistor divider. Leaving it floating or connecting it incorrectly can lead to incorrect voltage feedback and potentially improper charging behavior.
In charging mode, the internal connection to PGND is important for correct operation. In out-of-window conditions, the high-impedance state is a designed feature to minimize leakage.

FBG.name: FBG

FSW_SYNC.description: Switching Frequency and Synchronization Input – An external resistor is connected to the FSW_SYNC pin and PGND to set the nominal switching frequency. This pin can also be used to synchronize the PWM controller to an external clock with 200-kHz to 600-kHz frequency.

connected_components.description: An external resistor connected from the FSW_SYNC pin to PGND. The value of this resistor determines the switching frequency according to the formula R_FSW = 1 / (3.2 * 10^-9 * f_SW), where f_SW is the desired switching frequency. For example, a 133 kΩ resistor sets a switching frequency of 250 kHz.
An external clock signal can be connected to the FSW_SYNC pin for synchronization. The frequency range for synchronization is also 200 kHz to 600 kHz.

implementation.connectivity: Connect an external resistor from the FSW_SYNC pin to PGND to set the nominal switching frequency. This pin can also be connected to an external clock signal for synchronization.
implementation.detailed_description: The FSW_SYNC pin serves a dual purpose: it is used to program the switching frequency of the device by connecting an external resistor to PGND, and it can also synchronize the internal oscillator to an external clock signal within the 200-kHz to 600-kHz range.
implementation.functionality: Programming switching frequency and synchronizing to an external clock.
precautions: The FSW_SYNC pin must not be left floating. It should always be connected to PGND through a resistor or to an external clock signal.
The synchronization feature is intended for frequencies between 200 kHz and 600 kHz. Ensure the external clock signal falls within this range.

When using the synchronization feature, the EN_PFM bit in the MPPT_Control register (REG0x1A) is automatically cleared to 0 to ensure fixed-frequency operation. The host can re-enable PFM mode by setting EN_PFM back to 1 if desired.

FSW_SYNC.name: FSW_SYNC

HIDRV1.description: Buck Side High-Side Gate Driver – Connect to the buck high-side N-channel MOSFET gate.

connected_components.description: This is the power MOSFET that is switched by the HIDRV1 signal. It forms one half of the buck converter's half-bridge.

The BTST1 pin, connected to the source of the high-side MOSFET, along with the BTST1 capacitor and the HIDRV1 pin, forms a bootstrap circuit that provides the necessary voltage to drive the high-side MOSFET gate. The BTST1 capacitor is connected between BTST1 and SW1.

The SW1 node is the switching node for the buck side half-bridge. It is connected to the source of the high-side FET and the drain of the low-side FET. The BTST1 capacitor is connected between BTST1 and SW1.

implementation.connectivity: Connect to the gate of the buck high-side N-channel MOSFET.
implementation.detailed_description: The HIDRV1 pin is the high-side gate driver output for the buck side. It drives the gate of the high-side N-channel MOSFET in the buck converter.
implementation.functionality: It serves as the gate driver output to control the high-side buck MOSFET.
implementation.precautions: The HIDRV1 pin is a high-voltage output. Ensure proper PCB layout to manage switching noise and parasitic inductance. The voltage on BTST1 relative to SW1 should be monitored to ensure the bootstrap capacitor is properly charged for effective gate driving. The turn-on and turn-off resistance of the driver are specified in the datasheet and should be considered when selecting the MOSFETs.

HIDRV1.name: HIDRV1

HIDRV2.description: Boost Side High-Side Gate Driver – Connect to the boost high-side N-channel MOSFET gate.

connected_components.description: This is the power MOSFET that forms the high-side switch in the boost converter. HIDRV2 directly drives its gate. The source of this MOSFET is connected to SW2.

BTST2 is the bootstrap voltage supply for the high-side gate driver. A capacitor is connected between BTST2 and SW2 to provide the necessary bias voltage for HIDRV2 to drive the high-side MOSFET gate.

SW2 is the switching node for the boost side half-bridge. It is connected to the source of the high-side MOSFET and the drain of the low-side MOSFET. The BTST2 capacitor is connected between BTST2 and SW2.

implementation.connectivity: HIDRV2 should be connected to the gate terminal of the high-side N-channel MOSFET intended for the boost side of the converter. The source of this MOSFET should be connected to SW2.
implementation.detailed_description: HIDRV2 is the high-side gate driver output for the boost side N-channel MOSFET. It provides the gate drive voltage and current necessary to turn the MOSFET on and off during the switching operation of the boost converter.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of HIDRV2 is to drive the gate of the high-side MOSFET on the boost side of the converter. This involves providing a voltage swing sufficient to fully enhance the MOSFET's channel and delivering the necessary charge to achieve fast switching times. It works in conjunction with BTST2 and SW2 to create the necessary voltage for driving the high-side MOSFET.
precautions: Ensure the voltage on BTST2 relative to SW2 is within the specified limits for the gate driver. Typically, a bootstrap capacitor is used to charge BTST2 when the low-side MOSFET is on.
The gate drive loop formed by HIDRV2, the MOSFET gate, and the return path (SW2) should be kept as short as possible to minimize parasitic inductance and ringing.
The MOSFET chosen for the high-side boost position should have appropriate voltage and current ratings, as well as a low gate charge (QG) and gate-to-drain charge (QGD) for efficient switching.

HIDRV2.name: HIDRV2

ICHG.description: Charge Current Limit Setting – ICHG pin sets the maximum charge current, and can be used to monitor the charge current. A programming resistor to PGND is used to set the charge current limit as ICHG = KICHG / RICHG. When the device is under charge current regulation, the voltage at ICHG pin is VREF_ICHG. When ICHG pin voltage is less than VREF_ICHG, the actual charge current can be calculated as: IBAT = KICHG x VICHG / ( RICHG x VREF_ICHG). The actual charge current limit is the lower of the limits set by ICHG pin or the ICHG_REG register bits. This pin function can be disabled when EN_ICHG_PIN bit is 0. If ICHG pin is not used, this pin should be pulled to PGND, do not leave floating.

connected_components.description: A programming resistor connected from the ICHG pin to PGND. The value of this resistor sets the charge current limit (ICHG = KICHG / RICHG). The KICHG factor is approximately 50 A * kΩ with a 5-mΩ RBAT_SNS resistor. The range for RICHG is typically 0.0 Ω to 100 kΩ.

implementation.connectivity: Connect a programming resistor from the ICHG pin to PGND to set the charge current limit. The value of this resistor determines the charge current limit according to the formula ICHG = KICHG / RICHG. If the ICHG pin function is not used, it should be pulled to PGND. This pin can be disabled via the EN_ICHG_PIN register bit.
implementation.detailed_description: The ICHG pin is used for setting the maximum charge current and for monitoring the charge current. It allows for hardware-based setting of the charge current limit via an external resistor. When the device is operating under charge current regulation, the voltage at this pin is regulated to VREF_ICHG. If the voltage at the ICHG pin is lower than VREF_ICHG, it indicates that the actual charge current can be determined using a formula involving the pin voltage, the external resistor, and internal constants. This pin's function can be disabled via an I2C register bit.
implementation.functionality:
Yes, the ICHG pin has two primary functions:
1. Charge Current Limit Setting: An external resistor connected from ICHG to PGND sets the maximum charge current. The device regulates the voltage at this pin to VREF_ICHG when in current regulation mode.
2. Charge Current Monitoring: When the device is not in charge current regulation, the voltage at the ICHG pin is proportional to the actual charge current, allowing for monitoring.
implementation.precautions: If the ICHG pin is not used, it must be pulled to PGND to prevent floating. It is recommended to disable the ICHG pin function via the EN_ICHG_PIN register bit when it is pulled to PGND, although it is not strictly required.

ICHG.name: ICHG

ILIM_HIZ.description: Input Current Limit Setting and HIZ Mode Control Pin – ILIM_HIZ pin sets the maximum input current limit, can be used to monitor the input current and can be pulled HIGH to force device into HIZ mode. A programming resistor to PGND is used to set the input current limit as ILIM = KILIM / RILIM. When the device is under input current regulation, the voltage at ILIM_HIZ pin is VREF_ILIM. When ILIM_HIZ pin voltage is less than VREF_ILIM, the actual input current can be calculated as: IAC = KILIM x VILIM / ( RILIM x VREF_ILIM). The actual input current limit is the lower of the limits set by ILIM_HIZ pin or the IAC_DPM register bits. This pin function can be disabled when EN_ILIM_HIZ_PIN bit is 0. If ILIM_HIZ pin is not used, this pin should be pulled to PGND, do not leave floating.

connected_components.description: A programming resistor (RILIM_HIZ) connected from the ILIM_HIZ pin to PGND. The value of this resistor, along with the KILIM constant and the chosen R AC_SNS , determines the input current limit (ILIM = KILIM / RILIM). For example, with a 2-mΩ R AC_SNS, KILIM is 50 A*kΩ. To set a 10-A limit with a 5-kΩ resistor, the formula would be 10 A = (50 A*kΩ) / 5 kΩ.
If HIZ mode control is desired via this pin, it should be connected to a switch that can pull the pin above V IH_ILIM_HIZ (e.g., to a voltage rail) or to a controlled voltage source.

implementation.connectivity: Connect a programming resistor from the ILIM_HIZ pin to PGND to set the input current limit. If hardware current limit is not desired, or if HIZ mode control via this pin is not needed, this pin can be pulled to PGND. If HIZ mode control is desired via this pin, it should be connected to an appropriate voltage source or switch.
implementation.detailed_description: The ILIM_HIZ pin serves a dual purpose: it is used to set the maximum input current limit and to control the device's HIZ (High Impedance) mode.
implementation.functionality: 1. Input Current Limit Setting: A programming resistor connected from this pin to PGND sets the maximum input current limit. The device regulates the voltage at this pin to VREF_ILIM_HIZ when operating under input current regulation. 2. HIZ Mode Control: Pulling this pin above V IH_ILIM_HIZ forces the device into HIZ mode, disabling switching and the REGN LDO.
precautions: If the ILIM_HIZ pin is not used for hardware current limit setting, it should be pulled to PGND.
If the ILIM_HIZ pin is not used for HIZ mode control, it should be pulled to PGND.

The function of the ILIM_HIZ pin can be disabled by setting the EN_ILIM_HIZ_PIN bit to 0. When disabled, input current limit and monitoring functions, as well as HIZ mode control via the pin, are not available.
Pulling the ILIM_HIZ pin above V IH_ILIM_HIZ forces the device into HIZ mode. Ensure this is intended behavior when designing the circuit.

ILIM_HIZ.name: ILIM_HIZ

INT.description: Open Drain Interrupt Output – Connect the INT pin to a logic rail via 10-kΩ resistor. The INT pin sends an active low, 256-μs pulse to host to report the charger device status and faults.

connected_components.details: A 10-kΩ resistor connected from the INT pin to the logic rail (e.g., VCC or a system logic voltage).
The interrupt input pin of a microcontroller or other host system.

implementation.connectivity: The INT pin should be connected to the host microcontroller's interrupt input. Since it is an open-drain output, it requires a pull-up resistor to the logic rail.
implementation.detailed_description: The INT (Interrupt) pin is an open-drain output that signals changes in the charger device status and faults to a host processor. It asserts a brief, active-low pulse (256 μs) to report these events.
implementation.functionality: The INT pin's primary function is to provide an interrupt signal to a host microcontroller. It signals a wide range of events, including: valid input source detection/removal, entering/exiting DPM regulation, watchdog timer expiry, changes in charging status (including charge completion), TS status changes, thermal shutdown, battery overvoltage, and safety timer expiration. The specific events that trigger an interrupt can be masked by the host.
precautions: The INT pin is open-drain and requires a pull-up resistor.
Ensure the pull-up resistor value is appropriate for the system's logic voltage and noise immunity.
The INT pin can be used to immediately notify the host of critical events, so it should be properly configured and monitored by the host system.

INT.name: INT

LODRV1.description: Buck Side Low-Side Gate Driver – Connect to the buck low-side N-channel MOSFET gate.

connected_components.details: This is the external power MOSFET for the low-side switch in the buck converter topology. LODRV1 connects to its gate terminal.

implementation.connectivity: LODRV1 should be connected directly to the gate of the low-side N-channel MOSFET used in the buck configuration of the converter.
implementation.detailed_description: LODRV1 is the Low-Side Gate Driver output for the buck side of the bidirectional converter. It is responsible for driving the gate of the low-side N-channel MOSFET in the buck configuration.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of LODRV1 is to drive the gate of the low-side buck MOSFET. It is controlled by the internal logic of the BQ25756 to enable or disable the MOSFET's conduction during the switching cycle.
implementation.precautions: Ensure that the gate drive voltage provided by the BQ25756 (or an external supply connected to DRV_SUP) is within the operating limits of the MOSFET. The connection should be as short as possible to minimize parasitic inductance, which can affect switching performance and cause ringing.

LODRV1.name: LODRV1

LODRV2.description: Boost Side Low-Side Gate Driver – Connect to the boost low-side N-channel MOSFET gate.

connected_components.description: This is the primary component connected to the LODRV2 pin. The LODRV2 output drives the gate of this MOSFET, controlling its switching.
The REGN pin provides the bias voltage for the gate drivers. Although not directly connected to LODRV2, its voltage level is critical for the proper operation of the driver output.
The power ground (PGND) serves as the return path for the gate driver current and is also connected to the source of the low-side MOSFET.

implementation.connectivity: The LODRV2 pin should be connected to the gate of the low-side N-channel MOSFET on the boost side of the converter.
implementation.detailed_description: LODRV2 is the low-side gate driver output for the boost side of the buck-boost converter. It drives the gate of the low-side N-channel MOSFET in the boost half-bridge.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of LODRV2 is to control the gate of the boost low-side MOSFET. This involves turning the MOSFET on and off as required by the buck-boost converter's switching scheme to regulate voltage and current.
precautions: Ensure that the MOSFET connected to LODRV2 is rated appropriately for the voltage and current requirements of the application.
The gate drive voltage is supplied by the REGN pin, so ensure REGN is properly bypassed and within its operating voltage range.
Keep the trace from LODRV2 to the MOSFET gate as short as possible to minimize parasitic inductance, which can cause ringing.
The drive strength and switching speed of LODRV2 can be configured through register settings (e.g., REG0x3B, REG0x3C) to optimize efficiency and minimize switching losses.

LODRV2.name: LODRV2

NC_15.description: No Connect - Leave this pin floating, do not tie to PGND

implementation.connectivity: The pin should be left floating and not connected to any other pins or traces on the PCB.
implementation.detailed_description: Pin 15 is a No Connect (NC) pin. This means it is not connected to any internal circuitry of the BQ25756 IC.
implementation.functionality: The pin is designated as 'No Connect'. It does not perform any function within the IC.
implementation.precautions: It is important to ensure that this pin is not inadvertently connected to any other part of the circuit, as this could lead to unexpected behavior or damage to the IC. Leaving it floating is the recommended practice.

NC_15.name: NC

NC_16.description: No Connect - Leave this pin floating, do not tie to PGND

implementation.connectivity: The NC_16 pin should be left floating. It should not be connected to any voltage or ground, nor should it be connected to any other pins or components.
implementation.detailed_description: The NC_16 pin is designated as 'No Connect'. This means it is not internally connected to any circuitry within the BQ25756 IC.
implementation.functionality: This pin has no electrical function and is not used by the device. It is a 'No Connect' pin.
implementation.precautions: It is important to leave this pin unconnected to avoid any potential unintended electrical behavior or interference. Connecting it to power, ground, or any signal trace could lead to unexpected operation or damage to the device. Ensure that PCB layout does not accidentally connect this pin to other traces or components.

NC_16.name: NC

NC_31.description: No Connect - Leave this pin floating, do not tie to PGND

implementation.connectivity: The pin should be left floating and not connected to any signal, power rail, or ground.
implementation.detailed_description: This pin is designated as 'No Connect' and is not intended for any functional use by the device. It is a physical pin on the package that should be left unconnected in the schematic and PCB layout.
implementation.functionality: None. This pin is not connected to any internal circuitry of the BQ25756 and does not perform any function.
implementation.precautions: Do not connect this pin to any voltage source, ground, or signal trace. Connecting this pin may lead to unexpected behavior or damage to the device. It is recommended to leave this pin unconnected in the schematic and on the PCB layout.

NC_31.name: NC

PG.description: Open Drain Active Low Power Good Indicator – Connect to the pull up rail via 10-kΩ resistor. LOW indicates a good input source if VAC is within the programmed ACUV / ACOV operating window. The PG pin function can be disabled when DIS_PG_PIN bit is set to 1. When disabled, this pin can be used as a general purpose indicator via the FORCE_STAT3_ON bit.

connected_components.details: Typically 10 kΩ, connected between the PG pin and the logic rail.

implementation.connectivity: Connect to a pull-up resistor (typically 10 kΩ) to the logic rail.
implementation.detailed_description: Open Drain Active Low Power Good Indicator – LOW indicates a good input source if VAC is within the programmed ACUV / ACOV operating window. The PG pin function can be disabled when DIS_PG_PIN bit is set to 1. When disabled, this pin can be used as a general purpose indicator via the FORCE_STAT3_ON bit.
implementation.functionality: The PG pin indicates a power good status when the input voltage (VAC) is within the defined operating window (ACUV to ACOV). It can also be repurposed as a general-purpose indicator if disabled.
implementation.precautions: The PG pin function can be disabled via the DIS_PG_PIN bit. If disabled, it can be controlled as a general purpose indicator using the FORCE_STAT3_ON bit.

PG.name: PG

PGND_17.description: Tie this pin directly to PGND.

implementation.connected_components: This pin connects directly to the Power Ground plane, which should be a low-impedance path to the negative terminals of the input and output capacitors, and the source terminals of the low-side MOSFETs.
implementation.connectivity: Tie this pin directly to PGND (Power Ground).
implementation.detailed_description: PGND (Power Ground) is the ground connection for the power stage of the IC, specifically for the low-side gate drivers.
implementation.functionality: Serves as the ground return path for the power switching elements and associated gate drivers. It is crucial for proper operation of the buck-boost converter.
implementation.precautions: Ensure a robust connection to the power ground plane. Use multiple vias to connect to other ground layers for optimal current handling and thermal performance. Keep this connection as short and wide as possible to minimize inductance and resistance.

PGND_17.name: PGND

PGND_22.description: Power Ground Return – The high current ground connection for the low-side gate drivers.

connected_components.component_description: A dedicated low-impedance copper plane for power ground return, typically connected to the system's main ground.

implementation.connectivity: Connect this pin directly to the power ground (PGND) plane.
implementation.detailed_description: PGND (Power Ground Return) is the high current ground connection for the low-side gate drivers. It is also a power ground return for the overall device.
implementation.functionality: Power ground return for low-side gate drivers and the device itself. It serves as a primary ground connection for high-current paths within the switching converter.
implementation.precautions: Ensure a robust connection to the power ground plane, especially for high-current paths. Multiple vias to the ground plane are recommended to minimize impedance and improve thermal dissipation.

PGND_22.name: PGND

REGN.description: Charger Internal Linear Regulator Output – Connect a 4.7-μF ceramic capacitor from REGN to power ground. REGN LDO voltage can be used as the gate driver supply for all switching FETs by connecting REGN to DRV_SUP pin. In high-voltage applications, it is possible to directly provide the DRV_SUP voltage with an external supply up to 12 V to achieve higher switching efficiency. See Section 8.3.3.2 for more details.

connected_components.description: A 4.7-µF ceramic capacitor is required to be connected between the REGN pin and PGND for proper operation and stability of the internal regulator.

implementation.connectivity: A 4.7-µF ceramic capacitor should be connected from the REGN pin to power ground (PGND).
implementation.detailed_description: The REGN pin is the output of the internal linear regulator. It provides a regulated bias supply for the IC itself, external thermistors, and can also be used to drive the gates of the buck-boost switching FETs by connecting it to the DRV_SUP pin. Additionally, the pull-up rail for the PG, STAT1, and STAT2 pins can be connected to REGN.
implementation.functionality: REGN serves as a regulated voltage output (typically 5V) used for internal biasing and potentially for external components and gate drivers. It is enabled under specific conditions: when VAC is above the V_VAC_OK threshold and charging is enabled in forward mode, or when the battery voltage is above 3V and reverse mode is enabled.
precautions: In high-voltage applications or when driving large gate charges at high switching frequencies, the power dissipation through the REGN LDO can be excessive. In such cases, it's recommended to provide the gate drive supply externally by directly driving the DRV_SUP pin with a supply up to 12V for improved efficiency. This external supply should be capable of providing at least 50 mA.
The REGN LDO has under-voltage protection. If the REGN voltage falls below the REGN_OKZ threshold, the switching converter will stop operation to protect the device.

REGN.name: REGN

SCL.description: I2C Interface Clock – Connect SCL to the logic rail through a 10-kΩ resistor.

connected_components.details: A 10-kΩ resistor connected from the SCL pin to the system's logic voltage rail (e.g., VCC or VDD). This resistor is necessary for proper I2C communication as SCL is an open-drain output.
The SCL pin is connected to the SCL pin of the I2C master device (e.g., a microcontroller or DSP) which generates the clock signal for the I2C bus.

implementation.connectivity: Connect the SCL pin to the I2C clock line of the system. It should be connected to the logic rail through a 10-kΩ resistor.
implementation.detailed_description: SCL is the I2C Interface Clock pin. It is used to synchronize the data transfer between the BQ25756 and an I2C host controller.
implementation.functionality: The SCL pin functions as the serial clock input for the I2C interface. It is used to clock in the address, data, and command information sent to the BQ25756, as well as to clock out data read from the device. It is an open-drain output, meaning it requires an external pull-up resistor.
precautions: The SCL pin is an open-drain output and requires an external pull-up resistor to the logic supply voltage.
Ensure the pull-up resistor value is appropriate for the I2C bus speed and capacitance. A 10-kΩ resistor is recommended.
Do not leave the SCL pin floating. It must be connected either to the I2C bus or pulled to ground if not in use.
The SCL pin operates at logic levels, so ensure it is protected from voltages outside its specified operating range.

SCL.name: SCL

SDA.description: I2C Interface Data – Connect SDA to the logic rail through a 10-kΩ resistor.

connected_components.description: A microcontroller or digital signal processor that communicates with the BQ25756 via the I2C interface.
A 10-kΩ resistor connected from the SDA pin to the logic rail (e.g., VCC or REGN) to ensure proper I2C bus signal levels.

implementation.connectivity: Connect SDA to the I2C bus. It should be connected to the logic rail through a 10-kΩ resistor.
implementation.detailed_description: SDA is the I2C Interface Data line. It is a bidirectional data line used for communication between the BQ25756 and a host controller. Data is transferred serially through this pin using the I2C protocol.
implementation.functionality: I2C Interface Data
precautions: Ensure that the SDA line is properly terminated with a pull-up resistor to the logic rail.
Avoid leaving the SDA pin floating.
The SDA line is part of the I2C bus and should be routed carefully to minimize noise and interference, especially in high-frequency switching environments.
Ensure the I2C bus speed is within the supported range (100 kHz, 400 kHz, or 1 MHz).

SDA.name: SDA

SRN.description: Charge Current-Sense Resistor, Negative Input – A 0.47-μF ceramic capacitor is placed from SRN to SRP to provide differential-mode filtering. An optional 0.1-μF ceramic capacitor is placed from the SRN pin to PGND for common-mode filtering.

connected_components.description: A 5-mΩ resistor used to sense the battery charge current. SRN is connected to the negative terminal of this resistor.
Connected between SRN and SRP for differential-mode filtering of the current sense signal.
Connected between SRN and PGND for common-mode filtering of the current sense signal.

implementation.connectivity: Connect to the negative terminal of the battery current sense resistor (RBAT_SNS). A 0.47-μF ceramic capacitor is recommended between SRN and SRP for differential-mode filtering. An optional 0.1-μF ceramic capacitor can be placed from SRN to PGND for common-mode filtering.
implementation.detailed_description: Charge Current-Sense Resistor, Negative Input. This pin is part of the differential current sense interface used for monitoring and regulating the charge current. A filter capacitor is connected from this pin to the SRP pin for differential-mode filtering. An optional filter capacitor can also be connected from this pin to PGND for common-mode filtering.
implementation.functionality: It serves as the negative input for the charge current sense resistor. It works in conjunction with the SRP pin to measure the battery charge current. It is also involved in the battery voltage monitoring through the ADC.
implementation.precautions: Ensure proper filtering is implemented to avoid noise on the current sense signal, which can affect regulation accuracy. Connect to PGND if not used for current sensing.

SRN.name: SRN

SRP.description: Charge Current-Sense Resistor, Positive Input – A 0.47-μF ceramic capacitor is placed from SRN to SRP to provide differential-mode filtering. A 0.1-μF ceramic capacitor is placed from the SRP pin to PGND for common-mode filtering.

connected_components.details: A 5-mΩ resistor used to sense the battery charge current. SRP is connected to the positive side of this resistor.
A 0.47-μF ceramic capacitor connected between SRP and SRN.
A 0.1-μF ceramic capacitor connected between SRP and PGND.

implementation.connectivity: Connect to the positive terminal of the battery current sense resistor (R_BAT_SNS). A 0.47-μF ceramic capacitor should be connected between SRP and SRN for differential-mode filtering. An optional 0.1-μF ceramic capacitor can be connected between SRP and PGND for common-mode filtering.
implementation.detailed_description: SRP is the positive input of the charge current-sense resistor. A 0.47-μF ceramic capacitor is placed from SRN to SRP to provide differential-mode filtering. An optional 0.1-μF ceramic capacitor is placed from the SRP pin to PGND for common-mode filtering.
implementation.functionality: The SRP pin is used for sensing the battery charge current by measuring the voltage drop across the battery current sense resistor (R_BAT_SNS). This measurement is crucial for regulating the charge current.
implementation.precautions: Ensure the differential-mode filter capacitor is placed as close as possible to the SRP and SRN pins to effectively filter noise. Proper Kelvin sensing connections are recommended for accurate current measurement.

SRP.name: SRP

STAT1.description: Open Drain Charge Status 1 Output – STAT1 and STAT2 indicate various charger operations, see Table 8-6. Connect to the pull up rail via 10-kΩ resistor. The STAT1, STAT2 pin functions can be disabled when DIS_STAT_PINS bit is set to 1. When disabled, this pin can be used as a general purpose indicator via the FORCE_STAT1_ON bit.

implementation.connectivity: Connect the STAT1 pin to the pull-up rail via a 10-kΩ resistor.
implementation.detailed_description: STAT1 is an open drain charge status output pin. It, along with STAT2, indicates various charger operations. The functionality of these pins can be disabled, allowing them to be used as general-purpose indicators.
implementation.functionality: STAT1 serves as a status indicator for the charger's operation. It can be controlled via I2C to function as a general-purpose indicator when the primary status indication function is disabled.
implementation.precautions: The STAT1 and STAT2 pin functions can be disabled when the DIS_STAT_PINS bit is set to 1. If disabled, this pin can be used as a general purpose indicator via the FORCE_STAT1_ON bit.

STAT1.name: STAT1

STAT2.description: Open Drain Charge Status 2 Output – STAT1 and STAT2 indicate various charger operations, see Table 8-6. Connect to the pull up rail via 10-kΩ resistor. The STAT1, STAT2 pin functions can be disabled when DIS_STAT_PINS bit is set to 1. When disabled, this pin can be used as a general purpose indicator via the FORCE_STAT2_ON bit.

connected_components.connection: Connects between the STAT2 pin and the logic rail (e.g., REGN or VCC).

implementation.connectivity: Connect STAT2 to the pull-up rail via a 10-kΩ resistor.
implementation.detailed_description: STAT2 is an open drain charge status output pin. It indicates various charger operations in conjunction with STAT1. The STAT1 and STAT2 pins can be disabled, and in that case, can be used as general purpose indicator pins.
implementation.functionality: Yes, STAT2 can function as a general purpose indicator if disabled. When disabled, its status can be controlled via the FORCE_STAT2_ON bit.
implementation.precautions: The STAT1, STAT2 pin functions can be disabled when the DIS_STAT_PINS bit is set to 1. When disabled, this pin can be used as a general purpose indicator via the FORCE_STAT2_ON bit.

STAT2.name: STAT2

SW1.description: Buck Side Half Bridge Switching Node – Connect to the source of buck HS FET and the drain of buck LS FET. Connect the inductor between SW1 and SW2.

connected_components.details: An N-channel MOSFET used in the buck stage.
An N-channel MOSFET used in the buck stage.
The power inductor for the buck-boost converter.

implementation.connectivity: Connect to the source of the buck high-side N-channel MOSFET and the drain of the buck low-side N-channel MOSFET. The inductor is connected between SW1 and SW2.
implementation.detailed_description: SW1 is the switching node for the buck side of the buck-boost converter. It connects to the source of the buck high-side FET and the drain of the buck low-side FET. The inductor is connected between SW1 and SW2.
implementation.functionality: The SW1 pin is a switching node that carries high-frequency, high-current pulses. It is part of the power stage of the buck-boost converter.
precautions: SW1 is a high-current, high-frequency switching node. Proper PCB layout is critical to minimize noise and parasitic inductance. Ensure short and wide traces for this connection.
The SW1 pin can experience voltage spikes. Ensure that the connected components and PCB traces are rated appropriately.
Avoid connecting sensitive analog signals to the SW1 pin.

SW1.name: SW1

SW2.description: Boost Side Half Bridge Switching Node – Connect to the source of boost HS FET and the drain of boost LS FET. Connect the inductor between SW1 and SW2.

implementation.connectivity: Connect SW2 to the source of the boost high-side N-channel MOSFET and the drain of the boost low-side N-channel MOSFET. The inductor should be connected between SW1 and SW2.
implementation.detailed_description: SW2 is the switching node for the boost side of the half-bridge converter. It connects to the source of the boost high-side FET and the drain of the boost low-side FET. The inductor is connected between SW1 and SW2.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of SW2 is to serve as a connection point for the switching elements (MOSFETs) and the inductor in the boost converter stage. It's a power path for high-frequency switching currents.
precautions: SW2 is a high-frequency switching node and can generate electromagnetic interference (EMI). Proper PCB layout, including short and wide traces, and adequate copper planes, is crucial to minimize EMI.
Ensure that the connected MOSFETs are rated appropriately for the voltage and current seen at the SW2 node.

The voltage on SW2 can be significantly higher than the supply voltage (VAC or VBAT) due to the switching action and inductor voltage. Ensure all connected components are rated for these transient voltages.

SW2.name: SW2

TS.description: Temperature Qualification Voltage Input – Connect a negative temperature coefficient thermistor. Program temperature window with a resistor divider from REGN to TS to PGND. Charge suspends when TS pin voltage is out of range. Recommend 103AT-2 10-kΩ thermistor.

connected_components.details: A negative temperature coefficient thermistor is used to sense the battery temperature. A common choice is the 103AT-2, which is a 10-kΩ thermistor at 25°C. The NTC is connected in series with a fixed resistor, forming a voltage divider with the TS pin.

A fixed resistor is used in conjunction with the NTC thermistor to create a voltage divider. This resistor, along with the NTC, sets the voltage seen at the TS pin, which is then interpreted by the BQ25756 to determine the battery temperature. The value of this resistor is critical for defining the temperature thresholds and is chosen based on the NTC characteristics and the desired temperature operating range.

The voltage source for the voltage divider. Typically, the REGN pin (internal 5V LDO output) is used as the reference voltage for the divider. Alternatively, if the REGN LDO is not enabled or if a different voltage reference is preferred, the VCC or another suitable supply rail can be used. The choice of voltage reference impacts the calculation of the fixed resistor value.

implementation.connectivity: The TS pin should be connected to a voltage divider circuit. This circuit typically consists of the TS pin, a negative temperature coefficient (NTC) thermistor, and a fixed resistor. The NTC thermistor's resistance changes with temperature, thus altering the voltage at the TS pin. The fixed resistor is connected between the TS pin and a reference voltage (like REGN or VCC) or ground, depending on the desired NTC configuration and the specific temperature range being monitored.
implementation.detailed_description: Temperature Qualification Voltage Input. This pin is used to monitor the battery pack's temperature using a negative temperature coefficient (NTC) thermistor. The charging process can be suspended or adjusted based on the temperature readings. The temperature window for charging is programmed through the I2C registers, allowing for compliance with standards like JEITA.
implementation.functionality: The TS pin's primary function is to measure the battery temperature. Its voltage level is converted by an internal ADC to determine if the temperature is within the acceptable range for charging or reverse mode operation. If the temperature falls outside the programmed thresholds (e.g., too cold or too hot), the device will suspend charging or reverse mode, respectively. The specific behavior and thresholds can be configured via I2C registers (e.g., TS_Charging_Threshold_Control, TS_Reverse_Mode_Threshold_Control).
precautions: Ensure the NTC thermistor and the fixed resistor are of appropriate values to accurately reflect the battery temperature within the desired operating range. Refer to the datasheet for recommended NTC types and calculations for resistor values.
When the TS pin is not used (e.g., if temperature monitoring is disabled via EN_TS bit), it should be pulled to PGND. Leaving it floating is not recommended.
The TS pin voltage is monitored by an internal ADC. Ensure the voltage divider is correctly configured to provide a readable voltage within the ADC's input range.
In reverse mode operation, the TS pin also monitors temperature. The thresholds for reverse mode are configured separately using registers like BHOT and BCOLD.

The safety timer's operation (speed and suspension) can be affected by TS pin readings that indicate temperature outside the normal range. Ensure proper configuration of the JEITA profile and safety timer settings.

TS.name: TS

Thermal Pad.description: Exposed pad beneath the IC – Always solder the thermal pad to the board, and have vias on the thermal pad plane star-connecting to PGND and ground plane for high-current power converter. It also serves as a thermal pad to dissipate the heat.

connected_components.description: Power Ground. The thermal pad should be connected to PGND for proper operation and heat dissipation.
For effective heat dissipation, the thermal pad should be connected to the ground plane, often using multiple vias.

implementation.connectivity: It must always be soldered to the board. For high-current power conversion, it should have vias connecting to the ground plane and the power ground. It should be connected to PGND.
implementation.detailed_description: The exposed thermal pad beneath the IC is crucial for heat dissipation. It serves as a thermal pad to dissipate heat generated by the device during operation. It is also used as a power ground return for the low-side gate drivers and high-current power converter.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of the thermal pad is heat dissipation. It is also used as a power ground return. In high-current applications, it connects to the ground plane via vias for improved thermal and electrical performance.
precautions: Ensure the thermal pad is properly soldered to the PCB to facilitate efficient heat transfer.
For high-current applications, use multiple vias to connect the thermal pad to the ground plane to reduce thermal resistance and improve current carrying capability.
The thermal pad's connection to PGND is critical for both thermal management and electrical performance.

Thermal Pad.name: Thermal Pad

VAC_32.description: Input Voltage Detection and Power – Connect a 1-µF capacitor from pin to PGND. Pin 33 is the input bias to power the IC, and ACOV/ACUV resistor divider should be connected relative to pin 33. When Reverse Mode is enabled, pin 32 is regulated to VAC_REV.

connected_components.description: This capacitor is connected between the VAC pin (pin 32) and PGND to provide filtering and stable operation.

implementation.connectivity: Connect this pin to the system's input voltage rail (e.g., adapter or solar panel) in charging mode. In reverse mode, it will be regulated by the IC. A 1-µF ceramic capacitor should be connected from this pin to PGND for proper operation.
implementation.detailed_description: This pin, labeled VAC, serves as both the primary input voltage detection node and the power source for the IC itself. When the device is in charging mode, it is connected to the main input voltage rail. In Reverse Mode, this pin is regulated to a specific voltage (VAC_REV) to provide the output voltage.
implementation.functionality: Yes, this pin has different functions based on the operating mode. In charging mode, it detects and senses the input voltage. In reverse mode, it is regulated to provide the output voltage. It also serves as the bias voltage source for the IC.
implementation.precautions: Ensure the 1-µF capacitor is connected to PGND. The ACOV/ACUV resistor divider for over/undervoltage protection should be connected relative to this pin (pin 33 is also connected to the input voltage rail and used for the divider). When Reverse Mode is enabled, this pin's voltage will be regulated by the IC.

VAC_32.name: VAC

VAC_33.description: Input Voltage Detection and Power – Connect a 1-µF capacitor from pin to PGND. Pin 33 is the input bias to power the IC, and ACOV/ACUV resistor divider should be connected relative to pin 33. When Reverse Mode is enabled, pin 32 is regulated to VAC_REV.

implementation.connectivity: Connect a 1-µF capacitor from the VAC pin (Pin 32) to PGND. Pin 33 is also labeled VAC and should be connected to the same input voltage source. The ACUV and ACOV resistor divider networks for input voltage protection should be connected relative to Pin 33 (VAC).
implementation.detailed_description: VAC serves as the input voltage detection point and also acts as a power supply input for the IC. It is the primary connection for sensing the input voltage source and is also used to bias the internal circuitry of the IC. When the device operates in Reverse Mode, this pin is regulated to the specified VAC_REV voltage.
implementation.functionality: Input Voltage Detection and Power Supply Input for IC. In Reverse Mode, it regulates to VAC_REV.
implementation.precautions: Ensure proper bypassing with the 1-µF capacitor to manage input voltage ripple. When operating in Reverse Mode, the voltage on this pin will be regulated, so ensure the connected external components are suitable for this regulated voltage.

VAC_33.name: VAC
